step.context: \text{Which of the following equality is correct ?}
\text{What substitution will convert} \\ \int^{1}_{0} x \cdot e^{x^{2}} \, dx \rightarrow \dfrac{1}{2} \int^{1}_{0} e^{t} \, dt \, ?
step.reason: \text{Let } t = x^2 \implies \dfrac{dt}{2} = x \, dx \\ \therefore \int^{1}_{0} x \cdot e^{x^{2}} \, dx = \dfrac{1}{2} \int^{1}_{0} e^{t} \, dt \\

step.context: \text{So, what does the definite integral } \\ A = \int^{1}_{0} x \cdot e^{x^{2}} \, dx = \dfrac{1}{2} \int^{1}_{0} e^{t} \, dt \text{ evaluate to} ?
step.reason: A = \int^{1}_{0} x \cdot e^{x^{2}} \, dx =\dfrac{1}{2} \int^{1}_{0} e^{t} \, dt \\ \quad = \dfrac{1}{2} \left[e^t \, \right]^{1}_{0} \qquad = \dfrac{1}{2} \left[e^1 - e^0 \right]\\ \quad = \dfrac{1}{2} (e -1)
